question:
Of the eight students—George, Helen, Irving, Kyle, Lenore, Nina, Olivia, and Robert—in a seminar, exactly six will give individual oral reports during three consecutive days—Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon—according to the following conditions: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report. Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.

Which one of the following could be the schedule of the students' reports?
A) Mon. morning: Helen; Mon. afternoon: Robert Tues. morning: Olivia; Tues. afternoon: Irving Wed. morning: Lenore; Wed. afternoon: Kyle
B) Mon. morning: Irving; Mon. afternoon: Olivia Tues. morning: Helen; Tues. afternoon: Kyle Wed. morning: Nina; Wed. afternoon: Lenore
C) Mon. morning: Lenore; Mon. afternoon: Helen Tues. morning: George; Tues. afternoon: Kyle Wed. morning: Robert; Wed. afternoon: Irving
D) Mon. morning: Nina; Mon. afternoon: Helen Tues. morning: Robert; Tues. afternoon: Irving Wed. morning: Olivia; Wed. afternoon: Lenore
E) Mon. morning: Olivia; Mon. afternoon: Nina Tues. morning: Irving; Tues. afternoon: Helen Wed. morning: Kyle; Wed. afternoon: George
chain_of_thought: George can only give a report on Tuesday, and neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. In A, George is Tuesday morning, and Robert is Monday afternoon, so George’s rule is satisfied, but Olivia is Tuesday afternoon, which violates Olivia’s rule. In B, George is Tuesday morning, and Olivia is Monday afternoon, which also violates Olivia’s rule. In C, George is Tuesday morning, and Robert is Wednesday afternoon, which violates Robert’s rule. In D, George is Tuesday morning, and Robert is Monday afternoon, which violates Robert’s rule. In E, George is Tuesday morning, and Nina is Monday afternoon, so George’s rule is satisfied, and neither Olivia nor Robert gives an afternoon report, so both of their rules are also satisfied. So only E could be the schedule.
full_output:
<think>George can only give a report on Tuesday, and neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. In A, George is Tuesday morning, and Robert is Monday afternoon, so George’s rule is satisfied, but Olivia is Tuesday afternoon, which violates Olivia’s rule. In B, George is Tuesday morning, and Olivia is Monday afternoon, which also violates Olivia’s rule. In C, George is Tuesday morning, and Robert is Wednesday afternoon, which violates Robert’s rule. In D, George is Tuesday morning, and Robert is Monday afternoon, which violates Robert’s rule. In E, George is Tuesday morning, and Nina is Monday afternoon, so George’s rule is satisfied, and neither Olivia nor Robert gives an afternoon report, so both of their rules are also satisfied. So only E could be the schedule.</think>
<ans>E</ans>
hint_sentence: Consider each day's reports separately, starting with the day that has the most restrictions, and use the rules to eliminate options one by one.

D fails because if Nina gives a report on Tuesday, then Helen and Irving must give reports on Wednesday, but Kyle and Nina can give reports on Tuesday. If Robert gives a report on Tuesday, then George must give a report on Wednesday, which is not allowed because George can only give a report on Tuesday. question:
The organizer of a reading club will select at least five and at most six works from a group of nine works. The group consists of three French novels, three Russian novels, two French plays, and one Russian play. The organizer's selection of works must conform to the following requirements: No more than four French works are selected. At least three but no more than four novels are selected. At least as many French novels as Russian novels are selected. If both French plays are selected, then the Russian play is not selected.

Which one of the following could be the organizer's selection of works?
A) one French novel, two Russian novels, one French play, one Russian play
B) two French novels, one Russian novel, two French plays, one Russian play
C) two French novels, two Russian novels, two French plays
D) three French novels, one Russian novel, two French plays
E) three French novels, two Russian novels, one Russian play
chain_of_thought: No more than four French works are selected, so eliminate any option that has more than four French works. No more than four novels are selected, so eliminate any option that has more than four novels. At least three but no more than four novels are selected, so eliminate any option that has less than three novels. At least as many French novels as Russian novels are selected, so eliminate any option that has fewer French novels than Russian novels. If both French plays are selected, then the Russian play is not selected, so eliminate any option that has both French plays and the Russian play. Options A, C, and D fail the novel limit, E fails the novel limit and the French/Russian novel count, and B satisfies all conditions.
full_output:
<think>No more than four French works are selected, so eliminate any option that has more than four French works. No more than four novels are selected, so eliminate any option that has more than four novels. At least three but no more than four novels are selected, so eliminate any option that has less than three novels. At least as many French novels as Russian novels are selected, so eliminate any option that has fewer French novels than Russian novels. If both French plays are selected, then the Russian play is not selected, so eliminate any option that has both French plays and the Russian play. Options A, C, and D fail the novel limit, E fails the novel limit and the French/Russian novel count, and B satisfies all conditions.</think>
<ans>B</ans>
hint_sentence: The requirement "at least as many French novels as Russian novels are selected" can be satisfied in multiple ways, including selecting no novels at all. It is also worth considering the "if both French plays are selected, then the Russian play is not selected" condition in conjunction with the other requirements.

This is a contradiction because it combines the two sets of possible bays for grain, livestock, and textiles, so option D is the only option that cannot be the type of cargo held in bay 4.

Since we know that bay 4 is holding produce, and the bay holding produce is next to the bay holding textiles, and the bay holding textiles is bay 3, we know that bay 3 is holding textiles. So, the order of the bays is: bay 1: machinery, bay 2: fuel, bay 3: textiles, bay 4: produce, bay 5: livestock, bay 6: grain. Therefore, the type of cargo in bays 1, 3, 4, 5, and 6 is completely determined.

The following rules govern the assignment of parking spaces: Young must be assigned a higher-numbered parking space than Togowa. Xu must be assigned a higher-numbered parking space than Souza. Robertson must be assigned a higher-numbered parking space than Young. Robertson must be assigned parking space #1, #2, #3, or #4.

Since Robertson is assigned #1, #2, #3, or #4, and Robertson must be assigned a higher-numbered space than Young, Robertson cannot be assigned #5 or #6. This means Robertson must be assigned #1, #2, or #3. Young is assigned #5 or #6, so the only option that satisfies these rules is D, where Robertson is assigned #2, Young is assigned #6, and Togowa is assigned #1.
